title: Understanding Images as Data | Log #002
text:
Representation of Color Spaces
Images are described in different color spaces. We will only look at some important ways to represent images that are useful for machine learning tasks.

RGB (Red, Green, Blue)
RBG is the most common way to store pixel values. Each pixel contains 3 numbers between the values of 0-255. For example, red would be (255, 0, 0).
Grayscale
Grayscale images are represented using a single number per pixel between 0-255. 0 represents black, 255 represents white and the values in between are different shades of grey.
HSV (Hue, Saturation, Value)
HSV separates the color and intensity information in a way that’s more intuitive. There are many formats that are used to represent HSV, the standard format is as follows:

Hue - ranges from 0o to 360o and represents the color type
Saturation - ranges from 0% (no color, grayscale) - 100% (pure color) and represents the intensity of the color
Value - ranges from 0% - 100% and represents the brightness of the color


In the interest of keeping these blogs short, we will stop here and discuss diffent ways of image manipulation in the next ones.

text: Computer Vision refers to teaching machines to understand and extract information from images and video. title: Computer Vision | Log #001
text:
Computer Vision vs Image Processing
But before we get ahead of ourself, let’s understand what is the difference between traditional image processing and computer vision. Although they are related fields they differ in their approach and objectives.






Image Processing

Pixel level operations to manipulate and enhance images
Filtering, color adjustments, transformations
Works at lower level of abstraction with pixel-level features
Does not involve learning from data and less demanding



Computer Vision

Analysing image content and extract meaningful insights
Object Recognition, Segmentation, Tracking
Higher level of abstraction, analyzing contents of the image
Learning features and patterns from datasets and requires large resources

title: Computer Vision | Log #001
text:
Applications
Some of the main applications of computer vision are as follows:

Image Classification
Object Detection
Semantic Segmentation
Instance Segmentation
Pose Estimation
Face and Person Recognition
Image Restoration

title: Computer Vision | Log #001
text:
Challenges
There are many challenges in computer vision that we are yet to overcome such as accuiring accurate large datasets that are labelled, removing bias in datasets, choosing the right architecture for a model, real-time processing and optimizing the computational requirements, etc.
We will work on getting a deeper understanding into this field in the future blogs.
